video.title: Project Euler Challenges 1–4 - Coding Challenges with Florin
video.description:
Watch an experienced software developer (Florin Pop) work through the Project Euler challenges live.

00:00 - Intro
05:15 - Challenge 1 - Multiples of 3 and 5
12:58 - Challenge 2 - Even Fibonacci Numbers
20:30 - Challenge 3 - Largest prime factor
44:42 - Challenge 4 - Largest palindrome 

Connect with Florin Pop
🎥YouTube Channel: https://youtube.com/florinpop
🐦Twitter: https://twitter.com/florinpop1705
💻Website: https://florin-pop.com

topLevelComment.author: Madhukiran Attivilli
topLevelComment.text:
Florin, there is a bug in problem#3: Largest Prime Factor.
If x is  a factor of number A, and A/x=y, y is also a factor of A. When x=y, it becomes sqrt(A). So, if A is not a prime number, it would have atleast 1 factor between 2 and sqrt(A). All this is ok, in the context of determining whether A is a prime number of not.
But, u have used the sqrt(A) approach while computing the largest prime factor of A as well. This can sometimes fail. For example, consider A=123456. sqrt(A) is 351. Largest prime factor is 643.
Your algo failed becoz u r checking numbers between 2 and 351 (sqrt(A)) only. So, when A/x=y, and x<y, u are checking only from 2 to sqrt(A), and not checking from sqrt(A) till A.
So, to fix the bug in ur algo, for every factor "x" of A identified between 2 and sqrt(A), we should first check if y (=A/x) is a prime factor. When we do this, for A=123456, x=192, y=643, 643 becomes the largest prime factor even though sqrt(A) is 351.

topLevelComment.author: seba81uy
topLevelComment.text:
Hi I'm new to code and struggled cause the only  language I (barely) know is python but the solution for this problem I tried
x=target number
i=2

While x != 1:
     If x % i == 0:
     x=x/i
    Else:
    i += i
Print(i)

Nice video hope to be in the next stream

replies.author: Bum Bum
replies.text: Schnorzel1337 No i just asked what problem he did, I wasn’t talking about his code.

replies.author: Schnorzel1337
replies.text:
​@Bum Bum This solves nothing. Set the target to 3 and i increases to 4 in the first step making it impossible to break the while loop because x mod y is never 0 for y > x.

If you got infinite time you can set up a machine that uses the above code to determine if a number is a power of 2.

If the algorithm never terminates its not.
If the algorithm terminates it is.

Challenge 4 - Largest palindrome product:

Only loop down to the lowest possible n-digit number? 
for (let i = maxNumber; i >= minNumber; i--) // maxNumber = 999 & minNumber = 100

topLevelComment.author: Sergio Kornilov
topLevelComment.text:
Thank You for the video. Nice solutions.
But your first solution is pure bruteforce and you can improve it. You don`t need to check all numbers if they are divisible by 3 or 5. Instead you can build all numbers that are multiples of 3 or 5. For example 12 = 4 * 3 = 3 + 3 + 3 + 3. You can add 3 to a local variable until it is no bigger than "number". Same for 5.

replies.author: Schnorzel1337
replies.text:
@ClockFixerfor x in range(3,int(math.sqrt(n)),2): will work.
The 3 to start with an uneven prime.
sqrt(n) to precompute the limit and turning it from float to int.
stepsize of 2 because even numbers are never prime (unless 2).
